content:
Imagine you are a robot browsing the web, just like humans. Now you need to complete a task. In each iteration, you will receive an Observation that includes a screenshot of a webpage and some texts. This screenshot will feature Numerical Labels placed in the TOP LEFT corner of each Web Element.
Carefully analyze the visual information to identify the Numerical Label corresponding to the Web Element that requires interaction, then follow the guidelines and choose one of the following actions:
1. Click a Web Element.
2. Delete existing content in a textbox and then type content. 
3. Scroll up or down. Multiple scrolls are allowed to browse the webpage. Pay attention!! The default scroll is the whole window. If the scroll widget is located in a certain area of the webpage, then you have to specify a Web Element in that area. I would hover the mouse there and then scroll.
4. Wait. Typically used to wait for unfinished webpage processes, with a duration of 5 seconds.
5. Go back, returning to the previous webpage.
6. Google, directly jump to the Google search page. When you can't find information in some websites, try starting over with Google.
7. Answer. This action should only be chosen when all questions in the task have been solved.

Correspondingly, Action should STRICTLY follow the format:
- Click [Numerical_Label]
- Type [Numerical_Label]; [Content]
- Scroll [Numerical_Label or WINDOW]; [up or down]
- Wait
- GoBack
- Google
- ANSWER; [content]

Key Guidelines You MUST follow:
* Action guidelines *
1) To input text, NO need to click textbox first, directly type content. After typing, the system automatically hits `ENTER` key. Sometimes you should click the search button to apply search filters. Try to use simple language when searching.  
2) You must Distinguish between textbox and search button, don't type content into the button! If no textbox is found, you may need to click the search button first before the textbox is displayed. 
3) Execute only one action per iteration. 
4) STRICTLY Avoid repeating the same action if the webpage remains unchanged. You may have selected the wrong web element or numerical label. Continuous use of the Wait is also NOT allowed.
5) When a complex Task involves multiple questions or steps, select "ANSWER" only at the very end, after addressing all of these questions (steps). Flexibly combine your own abilities with the information in the web page. Double check the formatting requirements in the task when ANSWER. 
* Web Browsing Guidelines *
1) Don't interact with useless web elements like Login, Sign-in, donation that appear in Webpages. Pay attention to Key Web Elements like search textbox and menu.
2) Vsit video websites like YouTube is allowed BUT you can't play videos. Clicking to download PDF is allowed and will be analyzed by the Assistant API.
3) Focus on the numerical labels in the TOP LEFT corner of each rectangle (element). Ensure you don't mix them up with other numbers (e.g. Calendar) on the page.
4) Focus on the date in task, you must look for results that match the date. It may be necessary to find the correct year, month and day at calendar.
5) Pay attention to the filter and sort functions on the page, which, combined with scroll, can help you solve conditions like 'highest', 'cheapest', 'lowest', 'earliest', etc. Try your best to find the answer that best fits the task.

Your reply should strictly follow the format:
Thought: {Your brief thoughts (briefly summarize the info that will help ANSWER)}
Action: {One Action format you choose}
Confidence: {A float between 0 and 1 indicating your confidence level in the action. A higher value means greater confidence.}
Completion: {A float between 0 and 1 indicating how much of the task has been completed until now. Zero means no progress has been made and one means full completion.}

Then the User will provide:
Observation: {A labeled screenshot Given by User}

Now given a task: Find an Intermediate-level online course on Coursera about 'Blockchain Technology' which lasts between 1 to 4 weeks, and is provided by a well-known institution. Also, note the course's main goals and the instructor's name.  Please interact with https://www.coursera.org/ and get the answer.Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: To search for an intermediate-level online course on "Blockchain Technology," I should use the search functionality on Coursera. The search button is labeled [2], which will likely bring up a search textbox or allow me to enter my query.
Action: Click [2]
Confidence: 0.98
Completion: 0.1
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The search input box is now visible at [1]. To find relevant blockchain courses, I should type "Blockchain Technology" into this search box.
Action: Type [1]; Blockchain Technology
Confidence: 0.99
Completion: 0.15
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: There is a course titled "Blockchain Applications in Fintech" by INSEAD, labeled as a "Beginner · Course · 1 - 4 Weeks," and a specialization titled "Blockchain" by University at Buffalo for 3-6 months. The INSEAD course fits the required 1-4 weeks duration but is beginner level. No intermediate course appears in the correct duration range yet. I should scroll down to check for additional results that may fit the criteria (intermediate level, 1-4 weeks).
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Confidence: 0.95
Completion: 0.20
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The additional visible courses are all labeled as "Beginner" or have a longer duration than 1-4 weeks. There are still no intermediate-level courses in the 1-4 week format for "Blockchain Technology." It may be more efficient to use a filter for course level if it exists. I should scroll up to look for course level filtering options (such as Beginner, Intermediate, etc.) which are typically found near filter sections.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; up
Confidence: 0.9
Completion: 0.22
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The filter options for course subject and language are visible, but there are no visible filters for course level (e.g., Intermediate). The "Show more" button for subject options is present, but this won’t help filter by level. I need to scroll further or look elsewhere on the page for more filter options, possibly for course level.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Confidence: 0.85
Completion: 0.22
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The filter options for "Subject" and "Language" are clearly visible, but there are still no course level (Intermediate) or duration filters in view. The relevant courses listed are still labeled "Beginner." I need to scroll further down the page to check if there are additional filter groups or more results, possibly including intermediate-level options.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Confidence: 0.85
Completion: 0.22
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The courses displayed are still all marked as Beginner-level, and the left sidebar still only shows filters for Subject and Language, not for Level or Duration. There is still no option to filter by "Intermediate" or duration directly. I need to continue scrolling to see if Level filters become visible, as these are usually located further down in Coursera's filter section.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Confidence: 0.85
Completion: 0.25

Note that <textarea> or <input> may be textbox, but not exactly. Please focus more on the screenshot and then refer to the textual information.
[0]: <button> "Open Navigation Menu";	[3]: "(201)";	[5]: "(118)";	[7]: "(77)";	[9]: "(36)";	[10]: <button> "Show 3 more", "Show more Subject options";	[11]: <button> "Information about this filter group";	[13]: "(420)";	[15]: "(175)";	[17]: "(160)";	[19]: "(160)";	[20]: <button> "Show 25 more", "Show more Language options";	[21]: "Free Trial";	[23]: "Duke University";	[24]: "Blockchain Business Models", "Blockchain Business Models, offered by Duke University, COURSE";	[25]: "New";	[27]: "Packt";	[28]: "The Complete DeFi—Decentralized Finance—Industry Labs", "The Complete DeFi—Decentralized Finance—Industry Labs, offered by Packt, COURSE";	[29]: "Preview";	[31]: "INSEAD";	[32]: "Web3 and Blockchain Fundamentals", "Web3 and Blockchain Fundamentals, offered by INSEAD, COURSE";	[33]: "Free Trial";	[34]: "Free Trial";	[35]: "Free Trial";

content:
Thought: The course "Blockchain Business Models" by Duke University is labeled as Intermediate level, with a duration of 1–3 months—slightly longer than the required range. However, "The Complete DeFi—Decentralized Finance—Industry Labs" by Packt is also Intermediate, with a duration of 1–3 months. The course "Web3 and Blockchain Fundamentals" by INSEAD has a 1–4 week duration but is labeled "Mixed" rather than Intermediate. I should check the details for "Blockchain Business Models" by Duke University (a well-known institution) as it's closest in credibility and covers blockchain at an intermediate level (duration slightly exceeds requirement but is close).
Action: Click [24]
Confidence: 0.93
Completion: 0.7

Main goals/skills are visible: Financial Services, Cryptography, Blockchain, Emerging Technologies, Payment Systems, Business Logic, Network Protocols, Data Integrity, Digital Assets, Innovation, Financial Regulation.
